intro: Tragacantha mossulensis, commonly known as the Persian gum tree, is a deciduous shrub native to the arid regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant is notable for producing a resinous gum, which has been historically used in traditional medicine and as a natural adhesive. Its ability to thrive in harsh, dry environments makes it an important species in ecological restoration projects.
